### Derivation of the Functional Equation of the Zeta Function:

---

From [here](https://youtu.be/epmnnJSrDCY?si=3T0KsqTBoueZQl0N) and [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function#:~:text=The%20functional%20equation%20was%20established%20by%20Riemann,Magnitude%22%20and%20used%20to%20construct%20the%20analytic):

Start witht the gamma function:

$$\Gamma(s) = \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-t}  \, t^{s-1} \, dt$$

Consider instead $s/2$:

$$\Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right) = \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-t}  \, t^{\frac s 2-1} \, dt$$

Why? So that the denominator in $(\cdot)^{s/2}$ cancels out the $2$ in $n^2$ in the substitution that follows in the next line: 

Let $t = \pi n^2 x,$

$$\Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)= \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2 x}  \, (\pi n^2 x)^{\frac s 2 -1} \, \pi n^2 dx$$

Why? To later use the [Jacobi theta function](https://mathworld.wolfram.com/JacobiThetaFunctions.html).

Taking out terms:

$$\Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right) = \pi^{s/2}\, n^s \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2 x}  \, x^{s/2-1} \, dx$$

Rearranging,

$$\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)\,\pi^{-s/2}}{n^s} = \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2 x}  \, x^{s/2-1} \, dx$$

Summing on both sides:

$$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)\,\pi^{-s/2}}{n^s} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \int_{0}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2 x}  \, x^{s/2-1} \, dx$$
and rearranging:

$$ \Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)\,\pi^{-s/2} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac 1{n^s} =  \int_{0}^\infty \sum_{n=1}^\infty e^{-\pi n^2 x}  \, x^{s/2-1} \, dx$$
Or

$$ \Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)\,\pi^{-s/2} \, \zeta(s) =  \int_{0}^\infty  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \color{red}{\sum_{n=1}^\infty e^{-\pi n^2 x} } \, dx$$

Observe the similarity between the expression in red and the Jacobi theta function:

$$\Theta(x)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi n^2 x}$$

By symmetry of an even function,

$$\Theta(x)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{-1} e^{-\pi n^2 x} + 1 + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} e^{-\pi n^2 x}= 1 + 2 \, \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} e^{-\pi n^2 x}=1 + 2 \,\color{red}{\psi(x)}$$
We can split the initial equation as

$$ \Gamma\left(\frac s 2\right)\,\pi^{-s/2} \, \zeta(s) =  \int_{0}^\infty  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx= \int_{0}^1  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx + \int_{1}^\infty  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx= I_1 + I_2$$

Evaluating $I_1,$ and letting $x = 1/t,$ which means that $dx = - \frac{dt}{t^2}$:

$$I_1 =\int_{0}^1  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx=\int_{\infty}^1-  \, (1/t)^{s/2-1} \, \psi(1/t) \, \frac{dt}{t^2} = \int_{1}^\infty  \, (1/t)^{-s/2-1} \, \color{orange}{\psi(1/t)} \, dt$$

Because of the property of the Jacobi $\Theta$ that says that $\theta(x)=1/\sqrt x \, \Theta(1/x),$

$$(1+ 2 \psi(x))= \frac 1 {\sqrt x}(1 + 2 \psi(1/x))$$

and therefore,

$$\color{orange}{\psi(1/x)=\frac{\sqrt x}{2} + \sqrt x \, \psi(x) - 1/2}$$

so plugging this back into the orange expression in $I_1:$

$$I_1 = 1/2 \int_{1}^{\infty}t^{1/2 - s/2-1} dt + \int_{1}^{\infty}t^{1/2 - s/2-1}\psi(t) dt - 1/2 \int_{1}^{\infty}t^{ - s/2-1} dt$$

Evaluating the first and third integrals,

$$I_1 = -\frac{1}{1 - s}- \frac 1 s  + \int_1^\infty t^{-s/2-1/2}\,\psi(t)\,dt = \int_1^\infty x^{-s/2-1/2}\,\psi(x)\,dx-\frac 1 {s(1-s)}$$

Going back to the original expression,

$$ \Gamma(s/2)\,\pi^{-s/2} \, \zeta(s) = \int_{0}^1  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx + \int_{1}^\infty  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx\\=\int_1^\infty x^{-s/2-1/2}\,\psi(x)\,dx-\frac 1 {s(1-s)} + \int_{1}^\infty  \, x^{s/2-1} \, \psi(x) \, dx\\
= \color{magenta}{\int_{1}^\infty  \,( x^{-s/2-1/2}+x^{s/2-1}) \, \psi(x) \, dx -\frac 1 {s(1-s)}}$$

Using symmetry, let $s \to 1 - s,$

$$\Gamma\left(\frac{1-s}2\right)\,\pi^{-(1-s)/2} \, \zeta(1-s)= \int_{1}^\infty  \,( x^{-(1-s)/2-1/2}+x^{(1-s)/2-1}) \, \psi(x) \, dx -\frac 1 {s(1-s)}\\=
\int_{1}^\infty  \,( x^{s/2-1}+x^{-s/2-1/2}) \, \psi(x) \, dx -\frac 1 {s(1-s)}$$

which is the same as the expression in magenta. Therefore there is no change even if $s \to 1 - s.$ Therefore

$$\bbox[5px,border:2px solid red]{\Gamma(s/2)\,\pi^{-s/2} \, \zeta(s) =\Gamma\left(\frac{1-s}2\right)\,\pi^{-(1-s)/2} \, \zeta(1-s)}$$

is the functional equation.

#### Riemann Xi function:

From [here](https://youtu.be/epnPu9mx738?si=Uj9i-ReC3Go8jNXx) and [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riemann_Xi_function):

$$\xi(z)=\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-z/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 z)\, \zeta(z)$$
for $\Re(z) >1.$

This function can be extended to all complex numbers, and

$$\xi(z) = \xi(1 -z)$$

It is used to analytically continue the zeta function.

The proof starts off with the gamma function:

$$\Gamma(1/2 z) = \int_0^\infty t^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-t}\,dt$$

We'll proceed with the substitution 

$$t= \pi n^2 \, u$$
and $$dt= \pi n^2 \, du$$

Therefore,

$$\Gamma(1/2 z) = \int_0^\infty (\pi n^2 \, u)^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-\pi n^2 \, u}\,\pi n^2 \, du\\
= \int_0^\infty (\pi n^2)^{1/2 z} \, u^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-\pi n^2 \, u} \, du$$

Rearranging,

$$\pi^{-1/2z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,n^{-z}=\int_0^\infty  u^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-\pi n^2 \, u} \, du$$

Summing on both sides

$$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \pi^{-1/2z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,n^{-z}= \sum_{n=1}^\infty\int_0^\infty  u^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-\pi n^2 \, u} \, du$$
or

$$ \pi^{-1/2z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,\zeta(z)= \sum_{n=1}^\infty\int_0^\infty  u^{1/2 z-1}\, e^{-\pi n^2 \, u} \, du$$

Invoking the Fubini theorem

$$ \pi^{-1/2z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,\zeta(z)= \int_0^\infty \color{red}{\sum_{n=1}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2u}} \,u^{1/2 z-1}  \, du$$

Defining $$\omega(u) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2u}$$ the connection can be established to the Jacobi Theta function:

$$\Theta(z)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi n^2 z}$$

which has the property that

$$\Theta(z^{-1})=\sqrt z \Theta(z)$$
for $\Re(z) > 1.$

---

Proof:

$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi n^2 z^{-1}}$$

Doing a Fourier expansion (Poisson summation),


$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi t^2 z^{-1}}\, e^{-2\pi\, i\, n\,t}\,dt$$

Doing a $u$-substitution with $t = \sqrt z\, u \implies dt = \sqrt z \,du,$

$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \sqrt z\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi \, u^2 -2\pi\, i\, n\,\sqrt z \, u}\,du$$

Simplifying

$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \sqrt z\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi \, (u + i\,n\, \sqrt z)^2-n^2\,z \,\pi}\,du$$
Extracting out of the integral

$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \sqrt z e^{-n^2 \,z\,\pi}\,\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi \, (u + i\,n\, \sqrt z)^2}\,du$$

Defining $v= u + i\, n \, \sqrt z,$ 

$$\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-\pi \, v^2}\,dv=\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-(\sqrt\pi \, v)^2}\,dv$$

Substituting $t=\sqrt \pi v\implies dt = \sqrt \pi dv$ and we get the Gaussian integral:

$$\frac 1 {\sqrt \pi}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-t^2}\,dt = \frac {\sqrt \pi} {\sqrt \pi}=1$$

Therefore

$$\Theta(z^{-1}) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \sqrt z e^{-n^2 \,z\,\pi}=\sqrt z\, \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty e^{-n^2 \,z\,\pi}  =\sqrt z\, \Theta (z)\quad \square$$

Now we need to reconcile the limits of summation of $\omega(u)$ and $\Theta(z)$. We can split the limits of theta:

$$\Theta(z) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\ e^{-\pi\, n^2 \, z}+ \sum_{n=-\infty}^{-1}\ e^{-\pi\, n^2 \, z} + 1 \\
= \sum_{n=1}^\infty\ e^{-\pi\, n^2 \, z}+ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\ e^{-\pi\, n^2 \, z} + 1$$

by symmetry given by the $n^2.$

Therefore,

$$\Theta(z)=2 \omega(z) + 1$$

Now,

$$\color{lime}{\omega(z^{-1})}=1/2\,\left(\Theta(z^{-1}) - 1\right)\\
=1/2\,\left(\sqrt z\, \Theta(z)- 1\right)\\
=1/2\,\sqrt z\, \Theta(z)- 1/2\\
= 1/2 \, \sqrt z \, (2 \, \omega(z) + 1) - 1/2\\
= \color{lime}{\sqrt z \, \omega(z) + 1/2 \, \sqrt z - 1/2}$$

Going back to the equation above,

$$ \pi^{-1/2z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,\zeta(z)= \int_0^\infty \color{red}{\sum_{n=1}^\infty  e^{-\pi n^2u}} \,u^{1/2 z-1}  \, du\\
= \int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1}du + \int_0^1 \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1}du$$

Using the substitution, $v = u^{-1} \implies dv = -u^{-2}du$, and $-\frac 1{v^2} dv = du,$

$$\pi^{-1/2 z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,\zeta(z) = \int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1}\,\color{lime}{\omega(v^{-1})}\, v^{-1/2 z+1}dv$$

For the part in lime, we can use the identity derived above:

$$\pi^{-1/2 z}\, \Gamma(1/2z)\,\zeta(z) = \int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1/2 z -1}\,\color{lime}{(\sqrt z \, \omega(z) + 1/2 \, \sqrt z - 1/2)}\, dv\\
=\int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1/2 z -1/2}\,\omega(v)\,+1/2\, v^{-1/2 z -1/2}-1/2v^{-1/2 z -1}\,dv\\
=\int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1/2 z -1/2}\,\omega(v)\,dv+\int_1^\infty 1/2\, v^{-1/2 z -1/2}-1/2v^{-1/2 z -1}\,dv\\
=\int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1/2 z -1/2}\,\omega(v)\,dv+\frac 1 {z(z - 1)}$$

To make the RHS equal to $\xi(z)=\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-z/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 z)\, \zeta(z)$ we need to multiply both sides by $\frac 1 2 z(z-1).$ This will yield

$$\xi(z)= 1/2 + 1/2 z(z-1) \left( \int_1^\infty \omega(u)\, u^{1/2 z-1} du + \int_1^\infty v^{-1/2 z -1/2}\,\omega(v)\,dv\right)=\xi(z-1)$$

by symmetry of the dummy variables $u$ and $v$ in the integrals.

### Analytical Continuation of the Riemann Zeta:

Remembering the Xi function:

$$\xi(z)=\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-z/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 z)\, \zeta(z)$$

the zeta function can be expressed as

$$\zeta(z) = \frac{\xi(z)}{\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-z/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 z)}$$

And $\zeta(1 - z)$ as

$$\zeta(1-z) = \frac{\xi(1-z)}{\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-(1-z)/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 (1-z))}$$
But in the previous section it became clear that $\xi(z) = \xi(1-z).$ Therefore

$$\zeta(1-z) = \frac{\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-z/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 z)\, \zeta(z)}{\frac 1 2 z(z-1)\, \pi^{-(1-z)/2}\,\Gamma(1/2 (1-z))}= \color{red}{\pi^{1/2-z}\, \frac{\Gamma(1/2z)}{\Gamma(1/2(1-z))}}\zeta(z)$$

---

Two identities:

$$\Gamma(z) \, \Gamma(1-z) = \frac{\pi}{\sin(\pi\,z)}$$

and

$$\Gamma(z) \, \Gamma(z+ 1/2) = 2^{1-2z}\, \sqrt \pi \,\Gamma(2z)$$

---

So going back to the expression above in red,

$$\pi^{1/2-z}\, \frac{\Gamma(1/2z)}{\Gamma(1/2(1-z))}=\pi^{1/2-z}\, \frac{\Gamma(1/2z)}{\Gamma(1/2(1-z))}\frac{\Gamma(1/2 z + 1/2)}{\Gamma(1/2 z + 1/2)}$$

The numerator $\Gamma(1/2z)\, \Gamma(1/2 z + 1/2)$ matches the second equality above, whereas the denominator, i.e. $\Gamma(1/2(1-z))\,\Gamma(1/2 z + 1/2)$ matches the first equality because $1 - 1/2(1-z) = 1/2z + 1/2)$. Therefore,

$$\pi^{1/2-z}\, \frac{\Gamma(1/2z)}{\Gamma(1/2(1-z))}=\pi^{1/2-z}\,\frac{2^{1-z\,\sqrt\pi}\, \Gamma(z)}{\frac{\pi}{\sin(\pi(1/2- 1/2z))}}= \pi^{-z}\, 2^{1-z}\,\sin(\pi/2 - \pi z/2)\, \Gamma(z)$$

Therefore,

$$\zeta(1-z)= \pi^{-z}\, 2^{1-z}\,\sin(\pi/2 - \pi z/2)\, \Gamma(z)\, \zeta(z)$$

Since $\sin(\pi/2 -z) = \cos(z)$

$$\bbox[7px,border:2px solid red]{\zeta(1-z)= \pi^{-z}\, 2^{1-z}\,\cos\left(\frac{\pi z}{2} \right)\, \Gamma(z)\, \zeta(z)}$$

In the opposite direction [(see here)](https://math.stackexchange.com/a/437886/152225):

$$\bbox[7px,border:2px solid blue]{\zeta(z)=2^{z}\pi^{z-1}\sin\left(\frac{\pi z}{2}\right)\Gamma(1-z)\zeta(1-z)}$$

How to go from red to blue?

$$\zeta(z) = \frac{\zeta(1 - z)}{\pi^{-z}\, 2^{1-z}\,\color{green}{\cos\left(\frac{\pi z}{2} \right)}\, \Gamma(z)}=\frac{\zeta(1-z)\,2^z\, \pi^z\,\color{green}{2\sin\left(\frac{\pi z}2\right)}}{2\,\color{green}{\sin(\pi z)}\,\Gamma(z)}=\frac{\zeta(1-z)\,2^z\, \pi^z\,\sin\left(\frac{\pi z}2\right)}{\sin(\pi z)\,\Gamma(z)}$$

The trigonometric changes is because $2 \, \sin(\alpha/2)\,\cos(\alpha/2)=\sin(\alpha)$. Since $\Gamma(z) \, \Gamma(1-z) = \frac{\pi}{\sin(\pi\,z)}$, it follows that $$\Gamma(1-z) = \frac{\pi}{\sin(\pi\,z)\, \Gamma(z) }$$

Therefore the previous expression can be simplified as:

$$\zeta(z) = \zeta(1-z) \, 2^z \,\pi^{z-1}\,\sin\left(\frac{\pi z}2\right)\, \Gamma(1-z) \quad \square$$
